Description: Body sherd of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior glazed black; exterior: part of black band at join of lip and wall; handle zone reserved; glazed below; inscription on exterior.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis), Stratum AΠ145 (said to be)
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type A2 (possibly)
Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Although Schlotzhauer does not discuss this sherd, it possibly belongs to a Type 5C or Type 9A South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 5C cups are amongst the earliest South Ionian cups at Naukratis and are relatively rare at the site. Type 9A cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. Both of these cup types coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18), Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116), and Vallet and Villard's Ionian Cup Type A2 or B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 718, no. 760)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.111) (Phase 3)
